moves.1. e4: Not many people play e5 now.
moves.1... c5: Yes, the origanal is c5 or e5
moves.3. Nc3 d6: I don't like d6/d3 if the bishop is not out, otherwise its fine.
moves.4... g6: Black is already starting to weaken his kingside if he ever castles kingside (O-O)
moves.5. d4: This move is fine but the is a little scent of danger/pressure.
moves.5... f5: Black is simply starting to rot his kingside.
moves.6. dxc5: Now White's structure is a little bit better.
moves.6... fxe4: Well, now white can reply with Nxe4, also protecting his c5 pawn. Whatever black does, white will be a pawn up.
moves.8. Nxf6+: Now black has got a weak castling side whichever way he castles, he will end up in a weak side,
moves.8... exf6: Now black has two weak pawns (or 3).
moves.9. cxd6: I would think white needs to capture.But Qe2+ is maybe better.
moves.9... Qxd6: If a player is stronger than you, I think it is good to exchange queens. White should not exchange queens just yet and keep attacking.
moves.10... Qe7: I knew it. Black wants to exchange.
moves.11. c5: ??/!? Why make this move while White has other brilliant attacking plans like Be3/f4?
moves.11... Qxe2+: ? Now white can capture with Bxe2 and then White will win a tempo with O-O
moves.12. Bxe2 Bxc5: See. Now the pieces are equal.
moves.13. O-O: But black has terrible shape on the kingside.
moves.13... Bg4: I usally agree that knights are weaker than bishops (hearing the words of 'Knight after Bishops) so I think it is best to ignore.
moves.14. Re1: !! Now that is good! After Bxf3, Bxf3+ and white wins.
moves.14... Bxf3: Uh-oh for Black. Either Bxf3+ Be7 Bxc6+, King moves out of check, or Bxf3+ Ne7 Bxb7 and white wins.
moves.15. Bxf3+: Yes. And it is good to keep track of checks
moves.16. Bxb7: A Fine attack but then Rb8 changes nothing.
moves.17... Kf7: Now the knight is free to capture the bishop cuz the knight's not pinned anymore.
moves.18... Rhe8 19. Re2: Yes. Getting rid of the risk that Bxf2+ might happen.
moves.22. Rxe7+: !! There was the sacrifice that was brillaint. Whichever way black accepts it, white will always win a piece. Can you guess how?
moves.22... Rxe7: Ah. That's one way of escaping.
moves.23. Bd5+: Yes, of course. The nifty, rare bishop fork that never really occours. Well played for White. We never often have bishop forks, only Queen & Knight Forks.
moves.24. Bxc4: And now white swoops in a piece ahead.
moves.26... Bb4: ?! Also A dubious carless move. Not thinking what white would play next.
moves.27. f4: What has changed? Yes, white has unpinned the f2 pawn and sent it flying towards f4. Attacking the lonley rook.
moves.31... gxf5: But that could be declined. g5 solves the problem.
moves.32. Bf4+: That was the aim of the pawn sacrifice.
moves.32... Ke7 33. Bxf5+: White is five points up but we cannot be sure if he is going to win or not.
moves.35... Kg8 36. Re4: That is not the real aim.
moves.38... Rxa3 39. Bf5+: Now white is a whole bishop up.
moves.44. Kxg2 Bb2: What's the point of the sacrifice. Much better was Be6.
